titleStmt.title: Multi-Objective Fault-Tolerant Control for Fuzzy Switched Systems with Persistent Dwell-Time and Its Application in Electric Circuits

analytic.title: Multi-Objective Fault-Tolerant Control for Fuzzy Switched Systems with Persistent Dwell-Time and Its Application in Electric Circuits

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2019.2935685, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper concentrates on the output feedback controller design problem for discrete-time nonlinear switched systems with actuator faults. The Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model is adopted to approximate the nonlinearity of the plant with a set of local linear models. The persistent dwell-time switching law, which is more general than dwell-time or average dwell-time switching, is introduced to govern the switching among subsystems. In order to alleviate the effects of actuator failures on system stability and performance, a synthesized fault-tolerant output feedback controller ensuring various performance requirements is designed. Intensive attention is focused on establishing sufficient conditions which can guarantee the exponential meansquare stability as well as the prescribed extended dissipativity property of the closed-loop system. By virtue of the Lyapunov stability theory and appropriate matrix transformation methods, the desired controller gains can be obtained by solving a convex optimization problem. The developed method is finally applied to address the control issue of a tunnel diode circuit system model to illustrate its efficiency and applicability.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: D UE to the powerful capability of modeling practical systems encountering abrupt changes, switched systems have received considerable attention during the past several decades [1], [2]. They have been extensively applied to various fields, such as vehicle industry [3], electric circuits [4], manipulator robot [5] and biological networks [6]. For a switched system, the stability of the subsystems and the whole system cannot be mutually guaranteed, that is, even if all subsystems are stable, it is possible that the entire system becomes unstable under the regulation of certain unreasonable switching rule. [7]. Therefore, researches on the switching rules have received great attention from many scholars. Dwelltime (DT) switching, whose interval between two consecutive switchings is required to be more than a fixed constant τ DT , was first proposed by Morse to describe the switching of "high-level" controller in [8]. Soon afterwards, in order to relax the constraint that the activation time of each subsystem is larger than τ DT , the concept of average dwell-time (ADT) switching was introduced by Hespanha and Morse in [9], where the switching is required to be "slow on the average". Although current researches on DT or ADT switching are relatively extensive [10], [11], they may not be applicable on some occasions owing to the strict restriction on switching frequency. Therefore, a more general switching rule, the persistent dwell-time (PDT) switching, was provided to describe the intermittent occurrence of fast and slow switching [12], [13]. Under the PDT switching, the system alternatively switches between "τ -portion" (interval length no less than τ P DT ) and "T -portion" (interval length no more than T P DT ). In the Tportion, subsystems can switch among each other as long as the duration of each subsystem less than τ P DT , while in the τportion, there is only one subsystem activated [14]. Although PDT switching can describe the switching characteristic of the systems commendably, due to the complexity of switching rules, there is little literature on the output feedback controller design problem for nonlinear switched systems with PDT switching rule. That is the main motivation of this work.

On another research frontier, Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model, which enables us to utilize a set of local linear models and the corresponding fuzzy membership functions to approximate complex nonlinear systems, has attracted great attention [15]- [17]. Different from traditional analysis of neglecting the nonlinear part or using a single model to describe the nonlinear systems, the T-S fuzzy model focuses on regional linearization for nonlinear systems and using a set of IF-THEN fuzzy rules to classify different situations. In this way, complicated nonlinear systems may be transformed into easy-to-analyze forms that can be used to approximate many smooth nonlinear systems with any accuracy. Therefore, since the proposal of the T-S fuzzy model by Takagi and Sugeno in 1985 [18], numerous investigations have been carried out and lots of results have appeared on this topic. For example, the work in [19] fixed attention on the design of reliable switched controller for T-S fuzzy systems, where the switching mechanisms were introduced to categorize actuator failures. For T-S fuzzy Markov jump systems, an asynchronous filter was designed in [20]. The problems of output feedback control and state feedback control for T-S fuzzy systems were investigated in [21] and [22], respectively.

Additionally, when it comes to the study of nonlinear switched systems, a fundamental problem is to adopt a proper control strategy to guarantee the stability of the systems as it is essential for the normal operation of the systems. For the stabilization problem, most of the present works focused primarily on the state feedback control issue [1]. It is undeniable that the state feedback control scheme can guarantee the stability and performance of the systems more effectively by utilizing state variables which can reveal the internal characteristics of the entire system. However, in many practical situations, the state information of the systems is generally unmeasurable or partially available. In contrast, it is much easier and economical to obtain the output information of systems. Synthesized these factors, adopting the output feedback control scheme would be a superior choice [23]. Meanwhile, due perhaps to component failure, environmental disturbance and other factors, actuator faults are commonly encountered in practice. It is known that they may result in poor system performance or even instability [24]. To solve this problem, the fault tolerant controller design issue, which can ensure specified performance in the case of actuator failures, has been investigated extensively [25]. Besides, in the study of system performance, it is necessary to consider multiple objectives, such as output constraint, interference rejection, and passivity. Thus, designing a synthesized controller that can achieve multiple objectives has attracted increasing attention [26], [27]. Nevertheless, it should be mentioned that when the PDT switched fuzzy systems are taken into account, the problem of multi-objective fault-tolerant output feedback (MFTOF) control has not been investigated in the present work.
In view of the above discussions, in the paper, we are interested in designing an MFTOF controller for PDT switched T-S fuzzy systems. The contributions lie mainly in the following three aspects:

(i) As the first attempt, a synthesized MFTOF controller is constructed for discrete-time PDT switched T-S fuzzy systems. Different from [14], [28], the multiple performances are considered for PDT switched fuzzy systems for the first time by resorting to the extended dissipativity property index, under which the H ∞ performance, standard dissipativity property, passive property and l 2 -l ∞ performance analysis can be investigated in a unified framework. With the regulation of the MFTOF controller, the closed-loop system can maintain exponentially mean-square stable (EMSS) and meet multiple performance requirements in the presence of actuator faults.

(ii) In order to make the model constructed more in line with actual situations, the switching and nonlinear characteristics are considered simultaneously there. Different from the work in [29], [30], the PDT switching mechanism, which is more flexible than DT or ADT switching and can represent the intermittent occurrence of fast and slow switching, is introduced to govern the switching among subsystems. Compared with [31], [32], the mode-dependent fuzzy rules are taken into account as the nonlinearity of each subsystem may be different.

(iii) In view of a simple decoupling method, the gains of the output feedback controller can be readily presented on the basis of an algebraic constraint condition. In addition, the applicability of the proposed control strategy is verified by a numerical example and a tunnel diode circuit system model. The impact of actuator faults on system performance is investigated and the corresponding closed-loop state responses can be obtained. Notations: The notations employed in this work are standard. R a represents the a-dimensional Euclidean space; Z ≥b denotes the set of integers greater than b; ∥χ∥ means the Euclidean norm of vector χ; P > 0 means that matrix P is positive definite; λmax (B) ( λmin (B)) represents the maximum (minimum) eigenvalues of matrix B; sym{C} means C +C T ; the asterisk " * " signifies the symmetric block; l 2 [0, ∞) denote the space of square-summable infinite vector sequences over l 2 [0, ∞). Other conventional notations can be found in [6].

div.head: A. System Description
div.p: For a class of discrete-time switched T-S fuzzy systems, the θ-th rule of σ(l)-th fuzzy subsystem can be described as the following form:

div.p: and ω(l) ∈ R n5 are state vector, system measurement output vector, controlled output vector, input vector and external disturbance that belongs to l 2 [0, ∞), respectively; as a piecewise constant function of time l, σ(l) (l ∈ Z + ) represents the PDT switching signal taking values in a finite set M {1, 2, • • • , M }, where M is the number of subsystems;
div.formula: µ σ(l)s (l) (s = 1, • • • , p σ(l) ) stand for premise variables, S θ σ(l)s (s = 1, • • • , p σ(l) ) are corresponding fuzzy sets, p σ(l) is the number of premise variables; θ ∈ T {1, • • • , r σ(l) } with r σ(l) being the number of IF-THEN rules; A θ σ(l) , B θ σ(l) , C θ σ(l) , E θ σ(l) , F θ σ(l) , D θ 1σ(l) , D θ 2σ(l)
div.p: and D θ 3σ(l) are constant real matrices with appropriate dimensions. For simplicity, we denote A θ σ(l)
A θ i for each σ(l) i ∈ M, and other symbols are similarly defined.

Remark 1: At present, many researches on switched fuzzy systems assume that the division of fuzzy sets and the selection of premise variables are the same for each subsystem [31], [32]. However, in practical physical systems, it may be more reasonable to consider that the selection of fuzzy rule is various from different subsystems as the nonlinearity of each subsystem may be different. Therefore, in this paper, the fuzzy rule R θ i is considered to be mode-dependent. It can be noted that, when we choose R θ i = R θ (∀i ∈ M), the case degenerates to the same as [31], [32], which means the circumstance under our consideration may be more general.
The fuzzy weighting function is defined as
div.formula: g θ i (µ i (l)) = ∏ pi k=1 S θ ik (µ ik (l)) ∑ ri θ=1 ∏ pi k=1 S θ ik (µ ik (l)) where µ i (l) = [µ i1 (l), • • • , µ ipi (l)]; S θ ik (µ ik (l)) represents the membership degree of µ ik (l) in S θ ik . For ∀ i ∈ M, θ ∈ T , we have g θ i (µ i (l)) ≥ 0, ∑ ri θ=1 g θ i (µ i (l)) = 1
div.p: For the purpose of simplification, we introduce the notation that g θ i (µ i (l)) g θ i . Then, by fuzzy-blending of the above local models, the overall fuzzy model (Σ) of the i-th subsystem can be presented as
div.formula:      x(l + 1) = ∑ ri θ=1 g θ i [ A θ i x(l) + B θ i u(l) + D θ 1i ω(l) ] y(l) = ∑ ri θ=1 g θ i [ C θ i x(l) + D θ 2i ω(l) ] z(l) = ∑ ri θ=1 g θ i [ E θ i x(l) + F θ i u(l) + D θ 3i ω(l) ](2)

div.head: B. Fuzzy MFTOF Controller
div.p: In this part, we are committed to designing a fuzzy MFTOF controller which can guarantee the stability and multiple performances of the investigated system. The form of the controller under consideration is as follows

Remark 2: As shown in Fig. 1, the block diagram displays a typical structure of the fault-tolerant output feedback control for PDT switched fuzzy system. The case of actuator failures, which may affect the performance of the system or even cause system instability, is fully taken into account. It makes the issue under our consideration more general as actuator failures are frequently encountered in the actual situations. Meanwhile, considering that the state of the system is difficult to be obtained, the controller is designed by utilizing the measurement output y(l) of the system.

Remark 3: It is worth mentioning that gain faults and bias faults are two typical types of actuator faults which are commonly encountered in practice [33]. In this paper, the situation of actuator gain faults is considered. By choosing different values of f iυ , one can get different cases. For instance, the actuator is complete failure when f iυ = 0 is considered. However, the actuator operates in different states in most cases, as shown in (6). In the future work, we expect to take both gain faults and bias faults into account in the investigation of PDT switching fuzzy systems.

PDT Switching Mechanism
div.p: The switching of subsystems is supposed to comply with PDT switching rule. Therefore, before further analysis, the PDT switching mechanism will be explained in detail.
Definition 1: [34] For two positive integers τ P DT and T P DT , the switching signal σ(l) satisfies PDT switching mechanism if the following conditions hold.

i) There is an infinite number of non-adjacent intervals whose length is no less than τ P DT (the PDT). In each interval, σ(l) is a constant, and the intervals satisfying these conditions are called τ -portion.

ii) The τ -portion described in i) are separated by Tportion whose length is no more than T P DT (the period 1063-6706 (c) 2019 IEEE. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TFUZZ.2019.2935685, IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems of persistence). σ(l) can switch among each other in the Tportion as long as the duration is less than τ P DT .

As is shown in Fig. 2, a possible evolution of switching signal σ(l) with σ(l) ∈ M in the n-th stage is given to show the possible switching among subsystems. From Fig. 2, one can find that, in the n-th stage, the actual length of τ -portion and T -portion are τ (n) (τ (n) ≥ τ P DT ) and T (n) (T (n) ≤ T P DT ), respectively. In the τ -portion, the α-th subsystem is activated with its running time no less than τ P DT . In the T -portion, r-th, • • • , k-th subsystems are activated and the total running time is no more than T P DT . The switching instants of subsystems are l fn , l fn+1 , • • • , l fn+1-1 and l fn+1 , respectively. [l fn , l fn + 1] denotes the sampling interval, while [l fn , l fn+1 ] represents the switching interval. The switching among subsystems alternates between the τportion and the T -portion, which can be used to describe the phenomenon of alternating switching between slow switching and fast switching.

Remark 4: We use κ(l fn , l fn+1 ) to denote the total switching times in the interval [ l fn , l fn+1 ) . Obviously, the total sampling times are greater than the total switching times, which implies κ(l fn , l fn+1 ) ≤ T (n) + 1. In addition, for an arbitrary interval [l, t), one can deduce the following inequality [35] κ(l, t) ≤ ( t -l T P DT + τ P DT + 1

Remark 5: In [29], an asynchronous H ∞ controller was designed for discrete-time DT switched T-S fuzzy systems, and in [30], the stabilization problem for a class of ADT switched T-S fuzzy systems was investigated. However, when it comes to the controller design for PDT switched fuzzy systems, few kinds of literature have made relevant researches. Nevertheless, as demonstrated in [34], PDT switching is more general than DT or ADT switching, and they have the following relationship
div.formula: S DT (τ D ) ⊂ S ADT (τ D , N 0 ) ⊂ S P DT (δτ D , T )
div.p: where S DT (τ D ), S ADT (τ D , N 0 ) and S P DT (δτ D , T ) denote the sets of switching signals with DT, ADT and PDT property, respectively. Therefore, it may be more significant to study the control problem for PDT switched T-S fuzzy systems.

Remark 6: Obviously, both the actuator failures and the attenuation rate of Lyapunov function will affect the performance of the system. For actuator failures, different values of f iυ correspond to different degrees of failure. When we use η (0 < η < 1) and λ (λ > 1) to represent the sampling instant decay rate and the switching instant variation rate of Lyapunov function severally, η and λ will have an influence on the stability of the systems. Therefore, it is necessary to study the effects of f iυ , η and λ on the system performance index, which will be illustrated by a numerical example in Section IV.

div.p: In the rest part of this section, based on the conditions obtained in Theorem 1, the desired fuzzy MFTOF controller gains are given in Theorem 2 through the transformation and decoupling of matrix.

div.p: ) is similarly processed. Remark 8: Since practical systems generally exhibit nonlinear dynamics, many research efforts in recent years have focused on the stabilization of nonlinear fuzzy systems [45]. It can be noted that, those works are generally based on the assumption that the switching of the system is subject to stochastic switching mechanism. However, as stated in [46], in many hybrid systems, the switching may be governed by a supervisor, and in this case, it is more reasonable to consider the deterministic switched models. Therefore, constructing an MFTOF controller for PDT switched T-S fuzzy systems is a fascinating problem which deserves further investigation. In addition, to dispose of the actuator failures term L i in Ψ µ i , differ from the processing method in [47], we introduce some more flexible variables ε θφ i (i ∈ M, θ, φ ∈ T ), which are related to fuzzy rules and may be conducive for deriving criteria with less conservatism.

div.head: IV. ILLUSTRATIVE EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, two illustrative examples are given to demonstrate the validity of the designed fuzzy MFTOF controller proposed in Theorem 2. The main purpose is to explore the relationships among actuator faults matrix, sampling instant decay rate η, switching instant variation rate λ and system performance to verify the conclusion given in Remark 6. Corresponding open-and closed-loop state responses are given to show the effectiveness of our method.

Then the minimum values of ϑ for different η and λ are presented in Table III and Table IV, from which we can find the following two principles: (a) The minimum values of ϑ become smaller when η increases. It means that within limits, the sampling instant decay rate is bigger, the better performance of the system can be obtained. (b) The minimum values of ϑ become larger when λ increases. It implies that with the raise of the switching instant variation rate the system performance may become worse.

Remark 9: It should be noted that the influence of sampling instant decay rate η and the switching instant variation rate λ on the system performance is interdependent. Specifically, in certain range, the larger the sampling instant decay rate, the slower the Lyapunov function attenuation, and the better the system performance, but the function value at the switching time is relatively large. As λ > 1, which means that the fluctuation range of function value at the switching time is larger. It may lead to the deterioration of system performance. Therefore, the trends in Fig. 5 are within a certain range, beyond which the situation may be more complex.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper has investigated the fuzzy MFTOF controller design issue for PDT switched nonlinear systems with actuator faults. The PDT switching mechanism has been introduced to govern the switching among subsystems. For the purpose of tackling the nonlinearity of the systems, the T-S fuzzy theory has been utilized. The actuator faults have been fully considered and a fuzzy MFTOF control strategy has been adopted to make the controller more reliable. Sufficient conditions, which can guarantee that the resulting closed-loop system is EMSS and extended dissipative, have been derived by constructing suitable switched Lyapunov function and using appropriate decoupling method. Finally, the effectiveness and applicability of the proposed method have been verified by two illustrative examples, in which the effect of actuator failures and the variation rate on the multiple-objective performance index have been investigated. Since the derived criteria are sufficient conditions, how to reduce the conservativeness of 1063-6706 (c) 2019 IEEE. Furthermore, the network-induced phenomena are widespread in the data transmission of various systems. Therefore, applying the control scheme to T-S fuzzy PDT switched systems with network-induced phenomena is also a fascinating issue deserving further exploration.

div.p: This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grants 61873002, 61703004, 61833005, 61503002, the 333 Project (BRA2017380), a Project Funded by the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu, the Key Laboratory of Jiangsu Province., IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems 13 Jinde Cao (SM'07-F'16) received the B.S. degree from Anhui Normal University, Wuhu, China, the M.S. degree from Yunnan University, Kunming, China, and the Ph.D. degree from Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, all in mathematics and applied mathematics, in 1986, 1989, and 1998, respectively. He is an Endowed Chair Professor, the Dean of School of Mathematics and the Director of the Research Center for Complex Systems and Network Sciences at SEU. Prof. Cao was a recipient of the Obada Prize, the National Innovation Award of China and the Highly Cited Researcher Award in Engineering, Computer Science, and Mathematics by Thomson Reuters/Clarivate Analytics. He is a fellow of IEEE, a member of the Academy of Europe, a member of the European Academy of Sciences and Arts, a fellow of Pakistan Academy of Sciences, and an academician of the International Academy for Systems and Cybernetic Sciences (IASCYS).
